highlights.sentence: Cameron Diaz talks to Esquire magazine about her career.
She says "Sex Tape" is the first movie where she does nude work.

sentence.content: Cameron Diaz is feeling fearless.
With her 42nd birthday approaching on August 30, the actress is dismissing Hollywood&apost;s obsession with youth and embracing growing older with pride and an eagerness to try something new.
"I like being 41.
I love it," Diaz tells Esquire magazine in its August issue, on sale July 8.
"So much s*** just falls away.
Fear, mostly.
It&apost;s the best age.
That&apost;s when a woman knows how to work things, or she doesn&apost;t care about that anymore.
You just stop being afraid.
You don&apost;t worry about what men think.
You just don&apost;t worry that time registers anything awful."

Perhaps it&apost;s that perspective that helped lead Diaz to the July 18 comedy "Sex Tape," in which she and Jason Segel play a couple who accidentally share a home video of their intimate moments for all to see.
Obviously, neither Diaz nor Segel could be shy about showing some skin with a plot like that, but in fact, Diaz isn&apost;t just showing some skin.
She&apost;s showing everything.
"It&apost;s a first for me," she says of the nude work in the comedy.
"But Jason (Segel) gets naked, too.
It&apost;s just a part of the role.
So I did it.
I mean, you see everything."
While Diaz is still conquering career firsts, in her personal life she&apost;s content with where she is.
When the topic veers toward her decision not to have kids, Diaz explains, "it&apost;s so much more work to have children."
"To have lives besides your own that you are responsible for -- I didn&apost;t take that on," the actress continues.
"That did make things easier for me.
A baby -- that&apost;s all day, every day for 18 years.
Not having a baby might really make things easier, but that doesn&apost;t make it an easy decision.
"I like protecting people, but I was never drawn to being a mother.
I have it much easier than any of them.
That&apost;s just what it is.
Doesn&apost;t mean life isn&apost;t sometimes hard.
I&apost;m just what I am.
I work on what I am.
"Right now, I think, things are good for me.
I&apost;ve done a lot.
And I don&apost;t care anymore."
